markdownRemark.html:
Understanding the model

If we have the data ZZZ, we can formulate a linear model with:

Y=Xβ+ϵY = X\beta+\epsilonY=Xβ+ϵ

  • YYY = vector of responses
  • XXX = design matrix
  • β\betaβ = parameter vector
  • ϵ\epsilonϵ = vector of errors

Modelling Assumptions

  • Any model that adheres to at least A1 and A2 is considered a linear model

Estimating model parameters

1. Least-Squares (LS) estimation of β\betaβ

Given β=(β^1,...,β^p)T\beta = (\hat\beta_1, ..., \hat\beta_p)^Tβ=(β^​1​,...,β^​p​)T, we want to minimize R(β)=(Y−Xβ)T(Y−Xβ)R(\beta) = (Y - X\beta)^T(Y - X\beta)R(β)=(Y−Xβ)T(Y−Xβ).

  • From this, we obtain β^=(XTX)−1XTY\hat\beta = (X^TX)^{-1}X^TYβ^​=(XTX)−1XTY which shows that each β^j\hat\beta_jβ^​j​ is a known linear combination of the yiy_iyi​ responses.

Note that XTXX^TXXTX has the following properties:

  • Symmetric: (XTX)T=XTX(X^TX)^T = X^TX(XTX)T=XTX
  • Positive semi-definite: (look online) - when a matrix is positive semi-definite, its eigenvalues are all non-negative.

Notice that these properties correspond to the same properties of a valid variance matrix.

2. Estimation of σ2\sigma^2σ2

First, note that:

E[ϵi2]=σ2=E[ϵTϵn]E[{\epsilon_i}^2] = \sigma^2 = E[\frac{\epsilon^T\epsilon}{n}]E[ϵi​2]=σ2=E[nϵTϵ​]

Then we can form a “bias-corrected” estimate of σ2\sigma^2σ2, based on the known residuals ϵ^i\hat\epsilon_iϵ^i​:

s2=RSSn−ps^2 = \frac{RSS}{n-p}s2=n−pRSS​

where RSSRSSRSS denotes R(β^)R(\hat\beta)R(β^​) and is called the “Residual Sum of Squares” with n−pn-pn−p degrees-of-freedom.

Properties of β^\hat\betaβ^​ and s2s^2s2

1. β^\hat\betaβ^​

  • β^\hat\betaβ^​ is an unbiased estimator
E[β^]=E[(XTX)−1XTY]=(XTX)−1XTE[Y]=(XTX)−1XTXβ=βE[\hat\beta] = E[(X^TX)^{-1}X^TY] = (X^TX)^{-1}X^TE[Y] = (X^TX)^{-1}X^TX\beta = \betaE[β^​]=E[(XTX)−1XTY]=(XTX)−1XTE[Y]=(XTX)−1XTXβ=β
  • under the variance assumption (A2), we get
Var[β^]=...=(XTX)−1σ2Var[\hat\beta] = ... = (X^TX)^{-1}\sigma^2Var[β^​]=...=(XTX)−1σ2
  • we can also calcalate these results with linear combinations
Var[cTβ^]=σ2cT(XTX)−1cVar[c^T\hat\beta] = \sigma^2c^T(X^TX)^{-1}cVar[cTβ^​]=σ2cT(XTX)−1c
  • and for the standard error (SE) of β^j\hat\beta_jβ^​j​, the estimate of SD[β^j]SD[\hat\beta_j]SD[β^​j​]
SE[β^j]=s[(XTX)−1]jjSE[\hat\beta_j] = s\sqrt{[(X^TX)^{-1}]_{jj}}SE[β^​j​]=s[(XTX)−1]jj​​

2. s2s^2s2

  • our variance is…
Var[ϵ^]=E[ϵ^ϵ^T]Var[\hat\epsilon] = E[{\hat\epsilon}{\hat\epsilon}^T]Var[ϵ^]=E[ϵ^ϵ^T]
  • and our expectation…
E[s2]=ϵ^Tϵ^n−p=σ2E[s^2] = \frac{{\hat\epsilon}^T\hat\epsilon}{n-p} = \sigma^2E[s2]=n−pϵ^Tϵ^​=σ2

Application to R

1. Creating a linear model

y <- stack.loss # define response variable
# define predictors
x1 <- stackloss$Air.Flow
x2 <- stackloss$Water.Temp
x3 <- stackloss$Acid.Conc.

# create linear model
fit <- lm(y ~ x1+x2+x3)
# get key information on our linear model
summary(fit)

Now we can make predictions using our model via the predict function in R:

# predict stack loss from our 3 predictors at a given value
predict(fit, data.frame(x1=50, x2=21, x3=85), interval="confidence")

We can also obtain other useful results from our linear model

coeffs <- fit$coefficients # LEAST SQUARES ESTIMATES OF INTERCEPT AND SLOPE

fit$residuals              # RESIDUALS FROM FITTED MODEL

fit$fitted.values          # FITTED VALUES

X <- model.matrix(fit)     # DESIGN MATRIX

Further more, we can obtain the residual sum of squares (RSS), its degrees of freedom and the residual standard error sss:

RSS <- sum(cement.lm$residuals^2) # RESIDUAL SUM OF SQUARES
df <- cement.lm$df                # DEGREES OF FREEDOM
s <- sqrt(RSS/df)                 # ESTIMATE OF SIGMA
  • Note: this is an estimate of sigma as shown above in the section for estimating σ2\sigma^2σ2, where n−pn-pn−p is the degrees-of-freedom.
